document.title: National Standards for Personal Financial Education

jurisdiction.title: Jump$tart Coalition for Personal Financial Literacy

E8E2A6528F484A05B7C65333DCC3E216.description:
Investigate the types of insurance commonly available for
people to purchase.

80081A413F4F406591480DFE58CC1C10.description:
Provide examples of large financial risks that people buy
insurance for (e.g., health, auto, fire).

90DE16D9620C41019608EA5B8C8B796D.description:
Insurance is often purchased
to limit financial losses due
to risk.

937BBBECE96948F3AE40588469759B7B.description:
Develop a system to keep track of personal items and
handle small amounts of money.

19380818FFCA44A5A6497DEE2E52C7CC.description:
Give examples of life events for which emergency savings
could offset financial losses.

E1647AE575544BBDB84B43797B747ADD.description:
One way to cope with
unexpected losses is to save
for emergencies.

BC10EB1DB27B47C88FA46F2A133E8A95.description:
Identify types of risks that are difficult or impossible for
people to reduce or avoid.

8B1BAE681A9A4DC7A214D67DBB1054EB.description: Recommend ways to reduce or avoid a given risk.

775E5A600D044EDFADDEA5302D4EEE9C.description:
People who are exposed
to risks often try to reduce
or avoid the negative
consequences of those risks.

719CB376F96443F697F6D067AC2C016A.description:
Describe how valuable personal items might be lost or
damaged.

6D2DFED31CE74A33AACD9FBC6530DFAC.description:
Estimate the losses and costs associated with certain
physical and financial risks.

0C38EB779A954DB09E79FDEF8D2C8019.description: Give examples of risks that people and households face.

00DF98C0D2C644C5B65D5CBD3D48CD67.description:
People are exposed to risk
when there is a chance
of loss or harm. Risk is an
unavoidable part of daily life.

2BFA606BBD674664B4004433E9BEA027.description:
Discuss why a person might be reluctant to lend money
or personal possessions to someone who has a history of
not repaying previous loans.

A0AC508C90154ECF9CDD16B0FB73CA11.description:
Explain why a person might prefer to lend an item or
money to one person over another.

A013DDDD93114E8EB8817F018C7BBD61.description:
Lenders are more likely to
approve borrowers who do
not have a lot of other debt
and who have a history
of paying back loans as
promised.

B4002E1F04954D92A884256DA8728B14.description:
Discuss reasons people may prefer to buy something with
credit rather than paying cash.

B4D03C7EC9C94CADABE677FD1D174495.description:
Identify goods and services that people often purchase
with credit.

F6AC89DF5DD84CE59C4968A25241CAB9.description:
When a person pays with
credit, they have immediate
use of purchased goods or
services while agreeing to
repay the lender in the future
with interest.

19FF6EE9F3BA4AA7AED3FCF61466FB20.description:
Describe the reasons why businesses and individuals
sometimes lend money to others.Â

CA9741617AA34911B28D1FB258442FBE.description:
Explain why a person who borrows $100 to buy
something, often must pay back more than $100 at a
future date.

076C117884B94335BE610A2178F2C33A.description:
Interest is the price a
borrower pays for using
someone elseâs money, and
the income earned by the
lender.

931295A539584D0B9F9973937A0E3AC9.description:
Provide examples of financial goals that are suited for
saving versus investing.Â

C7043DEF01924057B02D35D69D741083.description:
Identify the similarities and differences between saving
and investing.

A39EAC21FCE14EB7A90D0EB099C725AB.description:
Low-interest savings
accounts are commonly
used for short-term financial
goals and emergency funds
because they are low risk.
When saving for longer-term
financial goals, people often
invest in riskier assets to earn
higher returns.

5CDA3DA03C4F45D6B6C909F55723E8C3.description:
Identify long-term financial goals that are most likely to be
achieved by people who regularly invest their money over
many years.

2362602CB7974FF88F50FC372E3EC54E.description: Explain why people invest their money.

09FF497A0F154ECCAF1039C40F88C51A.description:
People invest their money
so that it can grow over time
and help them achieve their
long-term financial goals.

EEB534DE96D9420E91C31B7021C148AA.description:
Compare the interest rates on savings accounts at two
financial institutions.

59D69BF9B8AD403DA7A9CF85E8BBAA28.description:
Explain why financial institutions, such as banks and
credit unions, pay interest to depositors.

92A6CECDAEE142C48717DF9955E8A84A.description:
Financial institutions often
pay interest on deposit
accounts to attract customers
to deposit money in their
institution.

3598339043B54332A4D1484268023B9B.description: Identify safe places for people to keep their money

6664833232D04E2086A4994D47DF2B6A.description:
Describe the advantages of saving money in an account
at a financial institution rather than keeping the money at
home.

DD4210D144ED4A648CDF08258D7E238F.description:
Safety and ease of access
are factors to consider when
deciding where to keep
savings.Â

CFDFAEC82E9F43CDB7A0877E42F250E2.description:
Explain how a personâs friends and family can influence
their values and attitudes about saving.

B13485A1D4DB48B291D5691F8E1BCB99.description:
Discuss how life circumstances and experiences can
cause people to differ in their values and attitudes about
saving and their ability to save.

288A54A18A38490B8A3E10868EF53CF4.description:
People differ in their values
and attitudes about saving.

C7A0B53C396142038B29D12A7BD0EFE3.description:
Describe ways that people can decrease expenses to save
more of their money.

80B37E6EE4E7477780ACDB8ECD4342E7.description:
Give an example to illustrate the importance of having
some money set aside for emergencies.

44A7B4137AC34F758C87DAF3FB8DC885.description:
Map out a savings plan designed to achieve a future
purchase objective.

BFC3C0C59C72493ABD8BEB4FD4F36831.description:
A savings plan is a plan for
setting aside money to pay
for a future need, goal, or
emergency.

8B215C249FD74B8194FD27322DBE9F86.description:
Find an example of an advertisement (in a newspaper,
magazine, on TV, social media, or online) that is designed
to influence people to spend money right away instead of
saving their money.

65869517FD4D408E8F82602FCE07BD62.description:
Give an example of buying something now versus saving
money for the future and explain how they would make
that decision.

6B0FDBDE13604BA19B67DACA7356C715.description:
Explain why it is often harder to save than to spend
money.

3B76F7C650D649F3913B7C1A37BC7288.description:
When people save money,
they are choosing not to
spend money today to be
able to buy something in the
future.

B253996DBF6F4BFBBCD87E4DA80CD268.description:
Compare the effects of using debit versus credit cards to
make purchases.

CADF49CFB58E47199031F5DC7C5C47EA.description:
Explain the similarities between paying for purchases
with cash, checks, and debit cards.Â

B72A6DE989C44A5C9CCFCC1475935770.description:
Payment methods for making
purchases include cash,
checks, debit cards, and
credit cards.Â

21F52F34D92A4321B5572F2ECBF42063.description:
Identify reliable sources of information when comparing
products.

8E23D189245140A5B911893D50B4A5F4.description:
Share examples of how price, spending choices of others,
peer pressure, or advertising influence a purchase
decision.

7275FAAAA00047BAB97E026AE148DDEB.description:
Explain how peer pressure can affect purchasing
decisions.

D35B4805521E41EDBEFECE7D01B3C22C.description:
Price, spending choices of
others, peer pressure, and
advertising about a product
or service can influence
purchase decisions.

5DA96C0500DE4E378FCC2508663BF13B.description:
Explain the costs and benefits of trading goods and
services between family members and friends.

EF7825A9A74147459588C8B9AA17F25C.description:
Compare the costs and benefits of purchasing an item for
people with different characteristics (e.g. age, income).

C50BD7E397594C7EB0D46A120F68801B.description:
Purchasing decisions have
costs and benefits that can
be different for different
people.Â

E4DF4F7588C349949A278CC07CA69D33.description:
Provide examples of financial choices that have
opportunity costs.

E598CE81E03447B89AB634B7060B4C8E.description: Define the concept of opportunity cost.

F9F4BC1C0ECC4855BB7F70298A5F1134.description:
When people make a
decision to use money for a
particular purpose, they incur
an opportunity cost in that
they cannot use the money
for another purpose.

7F5F5E54DCBC41F5AB9D53DFFCCF19DD.description:
Identify ways you spend your money to increase personal
satisfaction.

CD71D747B0EA415EAD979ECBB8E36A28.description:
Analyze how people differ in their values and attitudes
about spending money.

10EB72466D8347A2882F10783A84451F.description:
Describe ways that people in a community share the cost
of services available to everyone.

E5BCA39B0AE945D3BFE6065C99079110.description:
Money can be spent to
increase oneâs own or
another individualâs personal
satisfaction or to share the
cost of goods and services.Â

880614F402464DB8ADEE89A2B463C62A.description:
Prioritize future spending, taking resource limitations into
account.

FBB08C384C0042C698EF3BF1FF2EDAEA.description:
Brainstorm a personal list of goals for consumption of
goods and services.

BB2A0980065D4DFD88F707A0F1D234FC.description:
Give examples of differences in peopleâs preferences that
can influence their spending on goods and services.

D7D2F5A3DFC947018A7AFAE59B087018.description:
People differ in their
preferences, priorities,
and resources available
for consuming goods and
services.Â

4F4ED1A58CE441738D3F51B3577BF78D.description:
Explain why citizens are required to contribute to the cost
of fire protection, police, public libraries, and schools.

00791A68956C4FB6A0B0777B3EB9F665.description:
Describe examples of government-provided goods and
services that are paid for with taxes.

8057D3B5C3EF4A0AB32853A7B05B9397.description:
Most income is taxed by
the government to pay for
government-provided goods
and services.

A80C8212E7C1462D9707853E303DC2D8.description:
Discuss the pros and cons of families/caregivers paying
their children a weekly allowance.

16EF5B7261D94614926E5E3A420ED0B0.description: Explain the possible reasons for gifting money to others.Â

65900EF5251041A791965BAC1FF2F027.description:
Income can be received as
gifts or as an allowance for
which no specified work may
be required.

6AB8CC8822C94446B35DF53CE602F169.description:
Identify different types of property that can be used
by owners to earn rental income (such as apartments,
automobiles, or tools).

ACD570F61AB541918EE42283AF33335E.description:
List several examples of ways in which people can
earn income by lending their money or by renting their
property to others.

77B621264B2D4AADB1E00CECA622919E.description:
People can earn income by
lending money or by renting
their property to others.

C07859C446FE4BE4B4EEEF1DC99F743A.description:
Estimate how much income could be earned from a
business operated by children (such as a lawn service or
lemonade stand).

8DE7B93E0B6C41B893D4F6D6E0C3E8E1.description:
Name several famous entrepreneurs and their
businesses, and hypothesize why they succeeded or
failed.

A4AEE2891BD14FA5A16DCB9AA308A0C7.description:
List several businesses they would be interested in
owning as an entrepreneur.

538D652579F44FD987645CA4D2558DA7.description:
People can earn income by
starting a new business as an
entrepreneur or by owning a
business.Â

DEAF6CB2724941919BF88E4925ADC3A1.description:
Compare how the following individuals are typically paid:
food server, teacher, and realtor.

6AFA76A35DA74D6ABB41EBF34162319C.description:
Describe the difference between wages, salaries,
commissions, and tips.

F6A85574DBAD41B9831F3CDD4A58999F.description: Explain why employers pay people for their labor

C63400BB0E32414F9C6C73A4C0F355BF.description:
There are different ways
to be paid for labor,
including wages, salaries,
commissions, and tips.

74B9D06D54C647CCB38AEC9A39FA653D.description: Brainstorm ways to improve oneâs ability to earn income.

35D7DEE86CC94ADD8AA518988D138DC5.description:
Give examples of how an individualâs knowledge, skills,
and experience could affect their ability to earn income.

79209D783F0A4216BA0E4FA536C43513.description:
People may be able to
improve their ability to
earn income by gaining
new knowledge, skills, and
experience.

0878B88273E046ADB0798A30960A7632.description:
Discuss the types of knowledge, skills, interests, and
experience required for different types of jobs.

B901DDDBBD9E469EA0AC0189509A4403.description:
People have different job
choices depending on their
knowledge, skills, interests,
and experience.
